dan hill remarks : the core issue with green boundaries ( like the uk 's green belt ) is that , by concentrating green ' elsewhere , they can let urban development off the hook .
how would you create a more distributed model , where green is integrated into every street ?

to ensure green spaces with all new development , vancouver has many policies , including density bonuses ' where extra density in housing developments is granted in return for such public amenities as cultural facilities , parks , schools , and social housing .
after resisting it at first , our development industry now likes the system , because they find it increases the value of their projects .
this has led to large parks in the downtown core , particularly in newly developed neighbourhoods like yaletown and the more recent olympic village in false creek .
personally , i like the idea of the 10-minute city , which would ensure that every home is within roughly 10 minutes of a park .
i would also like to see all streets lined with trees .
adam greenfield asks : how do you intend to prevent the area within the proposed green zone from becoming the exclusive domain of the wealthy ?

it 's tough , because vancouver is one of the most unaffordable cities in the world ; however while vancouver is out of reach for many people in terms of owning a home , the green zone covers all of the broader region of metro vancouver .
this means there are large protected green spaces in every city in the region , including more affordable areas outside vancouver like maple ridge , surrey etc .
ok , you 've got three minutes to tell us about vancouver 's green belt and why it 's such a good idea .
go !
the green zone is our legacy for future generations .
vancouver has a reputation for its natural beauty , but few are aware that a decision was made years ago to ensure it stays that way .

as part of the first liveable region strategic plan established for metro vancouver in 1996 , 70 % the region was designated a green zone , protecting metro vancouver natural assets , including the north shore mountains , major parks , watersheds , and ecologically important areas .
metro vancouver 's municipalities identified the lands to be included in the green zone .
significant consultation was undertaken and ultimately , the green zone comprised the lands that municipalities designated to be protected from urban development .
this was important because municipalities have the power to protect these lands through their powers to regulate land use and acquire lands if necessary to protect them from development .
vancouver 's green zone the common feature of lands to be included in the green zone , said former surrey mayor bob bose , is that they are not to be urbanised .
they can have many other uses , but they are aside from urban development .
the green zone set metro vancouver apart from other cities around the world establishing the region as cities in a sea of green .

according to former metro vancouver planner ken cameron ( watch his interview here ) : what was n't immediately obvious was that we had created an urban containment boundary that forced us to make wise use of the land we had identified for the development of cities and towns in our sea of green .
metro vancouver can only sprawl out so much within the confines of the green zone .
this makes it easier for municipalities to focus on building compact communities and improving public transit pillars of metro vancouver 's liveable region strategic plan .
so , why should other cities adopt this idea ?
a green zone identifies and protects a city 's natural assets , including major parks , watersheds , forests and farmland .
citizens and future generations are ensured access to nature and agricultural land for food production .
it also provides a boundary to contain urban development , preventing sprawl and encouraging cities to focus on building compact , walkable communities .

adam greenfield asks : what 's the proposal here ?
bulldozing existing places and remapping them on the chicago grid ?
certainly not .
as i said , people live in cities ; wholesale teardowns are impractical , and possibly cruel .
( however , application to brownfield rehabilitation , or renovation of blighted areas , is plausible in the short-term . )
the point is to make a rationalised long-term plan now , and apply it when necessary or desired .
dan hill : works well for a certain kind of city , clearly .
yet how would you convey the value of the grid over other successful models the smaller italian city form , for example ?
certain streets ( one every half-mile , 1km , five-minute walk etc ) could be designated as primary routes , and widened over years .
in the meantime , parking restrictions could be expanded to ensure delivery time for essential services ( police , fire , sanitation ) is minimised .
all right , tom , you know the drill tell us the big idea in three minutes or less ¦ daniel burnham is a part of chicago lore .
his 1909 plan of chicago called for broad , arterial boulevards and public space .
many aspects of the plan were not adopted verbatim .
yet the plan 's residue can be seen virtually anywhere today .

for example , the lakefront lincoln park to the north , burnham park to the south , and grant park in the middle comprises 20 miles of virtually uninterrupted parkland , bike paths , beaches , ballfields and museums .
other spaces , like garfield park , are in the interior , putting open space well within reach .
but day-to-day living in chicago does n't happen in parks .
( it 'd be nice , but there 's money to make , and food and shelter to buy with it . )
people need to get from point a to point b. chicago 's grid was not burnham 's idea , and not unique to chicago .
it is more of a function of how land west of the colonies was divided up after the revolution , by the ordinance of 1785 .
main streets run in each cardinal direction , with eight blocks to a mile north of madison street , and ten blocks to a mile south of it .
so anybody in town can know where they are in relation to any other place , just by knowing the grid .
burnham took that grid and laid diagonal boulevards over it , to serve as main arteries feeding into the centre of the city .
only a handful of those original boulevards were built , but the idea was borrowed when planning the major expressways and ( to some extent ) the railways that radiate from downtown .
the overall result is a rational system that permits people and products to move as efficiently as possible around the city , while allowing room for places for people to recreate .
this can be applied to redevelopment projects in cities of any size but only over time .
you can not tear down cities and displace the people who live there .
but over years and decades , disorganised places can be reformed so as to make movement around a city efficient , and perhaps even enjoyable .
so , why should other cities adopt your idea ?
burnham said : make no small plans .
but his plan , of boulevards and public spaces , marked up a blank slate .
you ca n't knock down cities to remake them ; people live in them .
what you can do is mobilise residents to make cities more liveable .

the city has built extensions to the south ( a low income community with a heavy appalachian population ) to garfield park and pleasant run , and is also creating a connected trail along pogue 's run on the very diverse and mostly low income east side .

alexander ralston 's original plan for indianapolis created a city with incredibly wide streets intended to befit a city being designed as a capital for the new state of indiana .
like many sad cases in the late 20th century , these grand , originally public spaces had mostly been converted into one-way race tracks for automobiles , some six lanes wide .
the indianapolis cultural trail was designed to fix this and more .
it took public space away from cars and gave it to people along eight miles of downtown streets .

this in the form of a raised , separated bicycle path , pedestrian way , native landscaping integrated with green stormwater management ( bioswales ) , high density and pedestrian scaled lighting , unique signage , and even public art .
indianapolis cultural trail the trail also integrates a bike share system .
and it features stations for the city 's new all-electric car share program that will be the first us deployment of the paris blue car system .
this shows how it repositions the auto in the city for the 21st century , too .
no wonder the ( ahem ) new york times said , the trail is putting indianapolis on the map as a place to see bold innovation .
indianapolis cultural trail the cultural trail is also highly functional .
indianapolis has a very spread out 5.5 square mile downtown .
the trail connects downtown 's scattered cultural districts , helping to knit them together .
it also serves as a downtown loop connecting many of the city 's major bike trails into the core of downtown and to each other .
my favorite part of the cultural trail is that it makes things safe for children to bicycle downtown .
lots of cities have put in bike lanes and such downtown , but biking can still be daunting for adults , to say nothing of children .
in downtown indianapolis , bicycling is n't just safe for kids , it 's delightful !

indianapolis cultural trail i 'd love to see chicago build one of these on monroe st. from halsted to lake michigan so that families and kids from the west side of the city can safety bike to enjoy the lakefront .
another part of the cultural trail mix is its financing model .
federal grants , along with $ 27.5m in private donation , covered the entire $ 62.5m cost .
no state or local tax dollars were needed only city employee time for engineering oversight and such .
also , $ 5m of the capital funds went to seed an endowment to pay for operations and maintenance .
this helps ensure that tight budgets wo n't allow the trail to fall into disrepair from lack of maintenance .
a non-profit organization performs those activities under contract to the city government .

indianapolis cultural trail put it all together and it 's a unique mix that does more than just check a lot of boxes ; it embodies architect daniel burnham 's exhortation to the city builder to do his utmost to bring into being for these people something that shall be a joy to them .

adam greenfield asks : how do you propose to overcome the chinese state 's active hostility to the notion that internal migrants deserve any recognition or accommodation in the first place ?
this has been a challenge for us at included over the years , though on many levels the government recognises the importance of internal migration for economic growth and modernisation .
this can be seen through shifting policy happening in some second-tier cities .
included has always strived to balance working with the government and empowering the people we serve .
recent praise and support from local governments in china seem to reflect that this approach is working .
and why should other cities adopt it ?
when migrants enter our cities , they find exclusion and barriers to achieving their full potential .

our community centres help bridge the gap between migrants ' informal lives and the formal institutions of the city , helping them improve their lives , achieve success and ultimately better the cities in which they live .

how do you ensure a structure that is as enduring ( materially , socially and financially ) as the concrete shoreline it is trying to replace ?
materially : as long as the marine wood is taken care of , it lasts long .
since izmir has many harbours and fishing villages , everything required for maintenance is already in place .
socially : the modular nature of the structure makes it shrinkable , expandable and variable , responding to changing needs of the city .
and financially : the shoreline is the only open space left in overcrowded turkish cities , so municipalities prefer making investments there .
anna minton and the uel students ask : was it difficult to convince the city authorities to allow you to do this ?
we presented the structure as a boat , which does not leave any trace when it is removed and is for the public benefit .
since izmir has been trying to take action regarding the design of the shoreline , everyone was very willing and accommodating .
the permit process , to our surprise , was extremely easy .

another question here from richard rogers ' firm ( of which judge ivan harbour is a partner ) : rogers stirk harbour ( @ rshp news ) @ guardiancities # citiesday hong kong has a degree of separation between pedestrian and car , how do you imagine hong kong can reinvent this ?
martin fung ( @ fungmartin ) @ rshp news @ twitterid our bridge systems reconnects the pedestrian to our traffic infrastructure
judge ivan harbour asks : hong kong , with its density and topography , necessitates a degree of separation between pedestrian and car .
in other cities this separation has not been very successful , as is dilutes street life and often leads to personal safety and security concerns .
how can hong kong 's experience reinvent this concept in a better way ?
in hong kong , we are not just erecting bridges , we are in fact laying a web of elevated links to fit tightly on to our urban fabric .

our bridges are conceived not merely as independent , elevated structures , but more an organic , three-dimensional arterial system feeding up and down to connect street life on the ground with the various raised public levels of our buildings , infrastructures and green decks .
the success of its transformative impact hinges mostly on the extent of its connectivity and integrated planning in the vertical developments of a city .
guardian cities asks : will these spaces be publicly or privately owned ?

our bridge-web in hong kong is composed of both publicly and privately owned spaces , with their boundaries blurred seamlessly , augmenting or even interchanging their original functions : footbridges become retail decks and commercial arcades double as raised streets .
why should other cities adopt it ?
the web of skywalks will make cities vertically more walkable , more accessible , more adaptable , more sharable and more resilient .
by elevating our urban capital and liveability , this floating urban realm could elevate every city in the world to a height of public life that is above and beyond the ground !

transport is a major challenge for the middle and low income inhabitants of the world 's emerging megacities .

in meskal square ( the square of the cross ) , addis ababa 's spiritual and geographical heart , commuters form long queues to pile into communal minibuses .
not only are the minibuses cramped , they 're unsound and not even that cheap ethiopia , after all , imports all of its petrol .
but ethiopia , one of the fastest-growing non-petrol economies in the world , has been building dams to harness its bountiful hydropower , and cheap and abundant electric power is on its way .

the capital is banking on this abundant electricity to provide a solution to addis ababa 's mushrooming population , and an electric train is soon to surge through the city on this wave of cheap power .
the two 17km lines join the eastern neighborhoods to the western hills , and the northern historic town to the new southern suburbs .
the train 's high aerial tracks , now nearly complete , come together symbolically in the shape of a cross in the square of the cross itself .

la louve ( she-wolf ) , the co-operative store in la goutte d'or neighbourhood , makes high-quality , organic products - normally the preserve of well-heeled parisians - affordable to the area 's low-income residents .
its members just have to volunteer three hours a month , in order to be able to shop there at prices well below those of supermarkets .

talking to your neighbour is just the beginning .

what 's important and innovative is the collaboration between different active neighbourhoods and drafting the agreement with the city government ( the good collaboration pact , drawn up by the 20+ associations with city officials ) .
so our message is : even with an ignorant mayor and city government , do n't give up , but propose the ways to collaborate in the name of a more citizen-friendly urban development .
we are proposing a process of building trust .
judge anna minton and the uel students ask : how did you get all 20 neighbourhood associations round the table ?
was there funding ?
yes , it was an initiative called urban idea ( linnaidee in estonian ) , for which we got funding from the open society foundation of estonia .
but the initial idea to start collaborating among neighbourhood associations came from neighbourhood enthusiasts themselves .
why should other cities adopt it ?
if local residents care about a place , they should be cherished for that !

neighbourhood associations are good partners and an invaluable source of information and knowledge for the city government in urban development , since they unite the city inhabitants who care beyond their house walls or courtyard .

anna minton and the uel students ask : how time-consuming is this process ?
your film mentions mapping 5,000 resident 's views how long did this take ?
it is a fairly light process for both respondents and planners .
in this case , the average respondent needed about 10 minutes to map his or her ideas .
naturally , times vary between individuals and their mapping interests .
it took about a month to collect over 30,000 mappings from roughly 5,000 respondents .
judge dan hill asks : great to see civic participation platforms include the city planning department but it 's all in the execution .
ultimately , who decides , and how ?
all planning decisions are made by helsinki 's city council following variegated development processes .
but to prevent only the loudest voices getting heard , helsinki applies tools like maptionnaire to make civic engagement easier and more diverse .
this project essentially served decision-making by bringing about important information for planners and decision-makers .
why should other cities adopt it ?
helsinki 's example shows that residents can get excited about participatory planning , when done right .
place-based tools for e-participation and co-participation , like maptionnaire , allow masses to convey ideas about future development online or through facilitated workshops .
high participation levels mean valuable information for planners and resident commitment to growth patterns .

usman haque asks : who decides what is good and bad graffiti , ie the difference between colourful street art ' and illegal graffiti ' ?
there is no rule to define what is good or bad graffiti .

the idea was to create a series of painting in walls that will stand as a public art gallery , for people who do n't often go into art galleries or museums , along with ensuring that the public space remains for everyone , not just for the few who litter it .
dan hill asks : good .
but graffiti is partly about the citizen 's desire to make a mark who is producing the street arts , and how ?
how do you engage those who want to make a mark ?
well , graffiti is certainly partly about the citizen 's desire to make a mark on their environment .
but sometimes graffiti is simply vandalism , and not acceptable .
here , after we began to paint street art on both public & private walls , some of the city 's graffiti activists accepted an organised form of art rather than making the walls uglier .
the public spaces were available initially for local school artists .
but as the project gathered momentum it spread across other walls in the city , owned by the government or private owners .
people started painting of their own volition .
judge anna minton and the uel students ask : how are the artists chosen ?
initially the artists were brought in from the local art schools and supported by various public and private sector organisations .
but now the whole project has gathered momentum and everyone has become artist and owner of their own walls .
why should other cities adopt it ?
cities are searching for solutions to illegal graffiti , while emerging economies struggle to keep public space attractive for its citizens .
so painting our street walls solves two problems : it fills walls with colourful street arts and makes these place attractive for tourists and businesses , too .
you 've got our attention .
three minutes go !
fascinating indeed .
so what 's your city 's best idea , in 10 words ?
painting street walls to create a living , public art gallery .

adam greenfield asks : i could n't agree more .
but there 's nothing about this that 's particularly novel , is there ?
or unique to auckland ?
surprising to many , but auckland has for many years had the highest ownership of cars per capita it is sometimes called the city of cars .
so auckland 's look , feel and function was designed around the car .
this project has been more about a developing a new attitude or psyche for our city than merely a single project .
it is about instilling a behaviour change and changing our views as to what we want from our city .

people are finding a new love affair with their inner city in many respects , we are bringing back fond memories of a european-styled , human-scaled city ; one with street cars , where going downtown was something you did as a treat .
usman haque asks : there are a lot of goals cited , but it 's not clear from the video what exactly is being proposed to achieve these goals , whether technical , regulatory or logistic .
please clarify how the proposals do actually meaningfully put people back into space .
the approach turns traditional traffic engineering approaches on their head .
to traffic engineers , shared spaces are counterintuitive , so there has been a great effort made in terms of training and awareness raising .
all the shared spaces are design-led ; a collaborative team of urban designers , landscape architects and transport engineers ty form the design team .

the principles of shared spaces have had to be clearly understood by all the team to ensure that pedestrians have the priority over all other users , signs are kept to a minimum and regulatory rules support the overall outcome .
sounds great !
but i like everything .
our panel of judges , on the other hand , are made of sterner stuff .
and here they come judge dan hill asks : great to see shared spaces implemented extensively .
how did you work with car drivers and retailers , who often resist shared space ?
auckland responds : initially sceptical , most small businesses are now requesting that shared streets be rolled out further .
the massive increase in pedestrian numbers , the decrease in accidents and the uplift in hospitality spending have been clinchers .
developers are now purchasing properties in areas that are earmarked for change , because they know that value uplift will occur .
why should other cities adopt it ?
imagine a space where love can be declared , shop tills clang with delight and people flock among cars to twitter and dance .
auckland 's shared spaces provide a venue for all of life 's activities , 24/7 .
auckland is crafting a liveable city by designing liveable streets .
great .
you 've got three minutes .
go !
auckland has the highest ownership of cars per capita in the world .
to treat our car addiction , we 've transformed nine central streets into shared spaces that are not anti-car , just pro-pedestrian .
pedestrians are the economic powerhouse of vibrant entrepreneurial cities , not the car .
walkers have benefited strongly from the transformation of roads into flexi-people spaces .
what 's more , the street has n't just become liveable , some are now even edible , with vegetable and fruit gardens .
we 've partnered with the community , from indigenous kiwi groups to businesses and the institute of the blind .
people have spoken : these spaces are making auckland beautiful or there 's a real sense of resurgence , life , energy and creativity .
retailers have also enjoyed the rewards , with a rise of 140 % in footfall and a 430 % increase in retail spending .
it is clear : a city that builds for cars attracts cars , and a city that builds for people attracts people .
urban design techniques such as shared spaces can not only deliver substantial value but also foster pride in the city .
and the beauty is any city can do it !

the theme of this first world cities day leading urban transformations ' highlights the pioneering power of cities .
